summary: the rules of the game - chapter 5, checkmate | Nox on Patreon
title: the rules of the game - chapter 5, checkmate | Nox on Patreon
excerpt: Join Nox on Patreon to get access to this post and more benefits.
description:
“You’re right. I would do anything for my children. But that’s my children, not yours. So if I were you, and I wanted my daughter back in my arms, I would kneel.”

Daenerys takes another few steps forward. “That throne you desire so much, it means nothing. That crown, it means nothing. The Seven Kingdoms are Five and they do not answer to me as queen, they answer to the Council of Wardens. The power that was in that chair has no power anymore. If you want it so bad, take it. The thing is hideous to look at anyway.”

“Something one Queen does, can be undone by another,” Cersei growls.

Read the fifth and final chapter of the rules of the game a week before the public for only $1 a month!

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: So in regards to the discussion @oadara​ brought up here, that this above picture is actually likely from EP 8x04 and not 8x01,...
caption:
So in regards to the discussion @oadara​ brought up here, that this above picture is actually likely from EP 8x04 and not 8x01, I just noticed something that makes me more convinced that this picture IS from a later episode, and that is what is in the snow behind Jon and Dany:

Notice what’s in the highlighted sections? Body parts. Or, more specifically, body parts likely belong to soldiers from the Army of the Dead. If you check out the high-res version of the picture you can notice it a bit better, even though the parts are cleverly hidden underneath the snow.

So yeah, I don’t think this picture is from 8x01, but a later episode. Most likely 8x04 since, again, David Nutter did film with Kit and Emilia by themselves in Iceland, and was the only one who did so. This could be them maybe going back to Winterfell after the battle to survey the damage/battlefield. Or maybe they are at some other place that had a battle happening with the Army of the Dead, and they are looking over the aftermath of that.

summary: I want to thank Michele Clapton for creating beautiful new costumes for Cersei and Daenerys aka the Queens of the show. Her...
body:
I want to thank Michele Clapton for creating beautiful new costumes for Cersei and Daenerys aka the Queens of the show.

Her clothes design is as fabulous as usual and it makes both Queens look so awesome and pretty. 

Thank you Michele, and let the best fashion Queen win!

blog.name: rainhadaenerys
blog.title: Daenerys Targaryen is the love of my life

summary: I recently saw a post somewhere that criticizes Daenerys of having internalized sexism and patriarchal thinking because she...
question: I recently saw a post somewhere that criticizes Daenerys of having internalized sexism and patriarchal thinking because she believes in the kind of power that destroys and oppresses (military power), and she never questions it. The post also criticizes Dany's supposed lack of interest in learning Elia and Rhaella's stories. I know something is flawed about this that I can't quite put into words, so maybe you could give your thoughts? (I'm really sorry if I sound presumptuous.)
answer:
There’s a lot of things to discuss in your ask. First, the question of Elia and Rhaella. @nobodysuspectsthebutterfly made two posts about this, and you can read them here and here.

Saying that Dany has no interest of learning about Elia and Rhaella is very unfair. Most of what we know about Elia and Rhaella come from Oberyn, from Jaime, from the World of Ice and Fire book, and because Dany asks questions about them. Dany is interested in learning about them. This is Dany asking about her mother:

Ser Barristan went on. “I saw your father and your mother wed as well. Forgive me, but there was no fondness there, and the realm paid dearly for that, my queen.”

“Why did they wed if they did not love each other?”

“Your grandsire commanded it. A woods witch had told him that the prince was promised would be born of their line.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

“Tell me,” Dany said, as the procession turned toward the Temple of the Graces, “if my father and my mother had been free to follow their own hearts, whom would they have wed?”

“It was long ago. Your Grace would not know them.”

“You know, though. Tell me.”

The old knight inclined his head. “The queen your mother was always mindful of her duty.” He was handsome in his gold-and-silver armor, his white cloak streaming from his shoulders, but he sounded like a man in pain, as if every word were a stone he had to pass. “As a girl, though … she was once smitten with a young knight from the stormlands who wore her favor at a tourney and named her queen of love and beauty. A brief thing.”

“What happened to this knight?”

“He put away his lance the day your lady mother wed your father. Afterward he became most pious, and was heard to say that only the Maiden could replace Queen Rhaella in his heart. His passion was impossible, of course. A landed knight is no fit consort for a princess of royal blood.” – Daenerys VII ADWD

Dany also thinks a lot about Elia and her children, and asks questions about them:

Yet sometimes Dany would picture the way it had been, so often had her brother told her the stories. The midnight flight to Dragonstone, moonlight shimmering on the ship’s black sails. Her brother Rhaegar battling the Usurper in the bloody waters of the Trident and dying for the woman he loved. The sack of King’s Landing by the ones Viserys called the Usurper’s dogs, the lords Lannister and Stark. Princess Elia of Dorne pleading for mercy as Rhaegar’s heir was ripped from her breast and murdered before her eyes. The polished skulls of the last dragons staring down sightlessly from the walls of the throne room while the Kingslayer opened Father’s throat with a golden sword. – Daenerys I AGOT

She nodded. “There was a woman in a bed with a babe at her breast. My brother said the babe was the prince that was promised and told her to name him Aegon.”

“Prince Aegon was Rhaegar’s heir by Elia of Dorne,” Ser Jorah said. “But if he was this prince that was promised, the promise was broken along with his skull when the Lannisters dashed his head against a wall.”

“I remember,” Dany said sadly. “They murdered Rhaegar’s daughter as well, the little princess. Rhaenys, she was named, like Aegon’s sister. There was no Visenya, but he said the dragon has three heads. What is the song of ice and fire?” – Daenerys V ACOK

“But that was the tourney when he crowned Lyanna Stark as queen of love and beauty!” said Dany. “Princess Elia was there, his wife, and yet my brother gave the crown to the Stark girl, and later stole her away from her betrothed. How could he do that? Did the Dornish woman treat him so ill?”

“It is not for such as me to say what might have been in your brother’s heart, Your Grace. The Princess Elia was a good and gracious lady, though her health was ever delicate.” – Daenerys IV ASOS

“You saw my brother Rhaegar wed. Tell me, did he wed for love or duty?”

The old knight hesitated. “Princess Elia was a good woman, Your Grace. She was kind and clever, with a gentle heart and a sweet wit. I know the prince was very fond of her.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

As you can see, Dany is interested, and she constantly thinks about the injustice made against Elia and her children. Besides, if we know little about these women, this isn’t Dany’s fault. It’s GRRM’s fault for not being interested in writing about them. This is a problem in GRRM’s writing. I’m tired of seeing Dany being blamed for the problems in the narrative. These problems aren’t her fault. I’ve also seen people in the fandom criticize Dany for this line:

“But that was the tourney when he crowned Lyanna Stark as queen of love and beauty!” said Dany. “Princess Elia was there, his wife, and yet my brother gave the crown to the Stark girl, and later stole her away from her betrothed. How could he do that? Did the Dornish woman treat him so ill?”

Antis say that Dany is “victim blaming” Elia. But I also think this criticism is very unfair. Because everything that Dany knows about Rhaegar from other people has been positive. She has been told all of these stories about how Rhaegar was honorable, just and good. With all of that, she can’t imagine why would Rhaegar publicly humiliate his wife. She even asks “how could he do that?” She’s appalled by the idea that Rhaegar would do something like that, so she asks for an explanation. Then, she tells Ser Barristan about what Viserys would tell her, how he used to be an emotionally abusive asshole that blamed both her and Elia for Rhaegar not being happy:

“It is not for such as me to say what might have been in your brother’s heart, Your Grace. The Princess Elia was a good and gracious lady, though her health was ever delicate.” 

Dany pulled the lion pelt tighter about her shoulders. “Viserys said once that it was my fault, for being born too late.” She had denied it hotly, she remembered, going so far as to tell Viserys that it was his fault for not being born a girl. He beat her cruelly for that insolence. “If I had been born more timely, he said, Rhaegar would have married me instead of Elia, and it would all have come out different. If Rhaegar had been happy in his wife, he would not have needed the Stark girl.” – Daenerys IV ASOS

I’m sorry, but Dany doesn’t know the full story, and even worse, she had Viserys telling her all these incorrect things. Viserys even emotionally and physically abused her for questioning his version of the facts. I’m tired of seeing this fandom blame Dany for things that she doesn’t know, as if she’s somehow obligated to be omniscient and know all the bad stuff about Rhaegar and her father. Dany doesn’t know that. For all she knew, Rhaegar was a very good person, so it’s natural that she would ask for an explanation about what happened. But notice that when Ser Barristan tells her the truth, Dany never tries to contradict him. She never tells him “no, you’re lying, Elia must have done something bad, she must be blamed”. Dany DOES NOT blame Elia. She was simply asking a question, because she doesn’t know anything about what happened.

Finally, let’s talk about this idea that Dany believes in “a power that destroys and oppresses”. I think there are different levels of wrong with this.

First: antis seem to have this idea that the only way Dany knows how to keep power is through war and force (hard power). This is wrong. Dany’s entire storyline in ADWD is about making compromises to keep peace, using soft power, and rebuilding (the only thing Dany is “destroying” is the slave trade). Dany dislikes violence. She’s actually a very flexible ruler that tries everything she can to accommodate the needs of different people: she adapts to other cultures, she makes several concessions in Meereen, she tries everything she can to find peaceful solutions. The idea that Dany only maintains power through violence and destruction and that she “doesn’t question it” is ridiculously wrong:

What good is peace if it must be purchased with the blood of little children? “These murders are not their doing,” Dany told the Green Grace, feebly. “I am no butcher queen.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

“Zhak and Pahl and Merreq. Them, and all the rest. The Great Masters. Who else would it be?”

He is as bold as he is bloody. “We have no proof this is their work. Would you have me slaughter my own subjects?”

[…]

“Then winkle them out of their pyramids on some pretext. A wedding might serve. Why not? Promise your hand to Hizdahr and all the Great Masters will come to see you married. When they gather in the Temple of the Graces, turn us loose upon them.”

Dany was appalled. He is a monster. A gallant monster, but a monster still. “Do you take me for the Butcher King?”

“Better the butcher than the meat. All kings are butchers. Are queens so different?”

“This queen is.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

Only at the end of ADWD does Dany reject the peace, and the reason for that is that the peace was unjust. Dany had to accept things like seeing people dying in the fighting pits and allowing slavery to return outside Meereen. A peace with slavery means that people will suffer continuous violence (slaves are beaten, raped, mutilated, overworked, treated like things). A peace with slavery is no true peace. I think Dany is right in being unsatisfied with a peace like that.

Second: this idea that any ruler could eschew military power is ridiculous. @instantbouquetface-me wrote a great post about this. You can read it here. But basically, as Max Weber says, any state “claims the monopoly of the legitimate use of physical force within a given territory”. Military power is part of that. Unless antis want Dany to help Westeros or Meereen to become an anarchy (I highly doubt that), then she needs military power as well. That’s how everyone (Starks, Targaryens, Lannisters, everyone) gains and keeps power. The Starks didn’t become Kings in the North by asking politely and making friends. They became Kings in the North through conquest.

Even rulers that are considered to be conciliators, like Jaehaerys and Alysanne, kept their power through threat of violence. Actually, no one would need to make compromises if military power wasn’t important. The reason Dany has to make compromises in Meereen is because she doesn’t have enough military power to defeat her enemies (and her dragons are chained), and because her enemies have military and economic power that they can use against her. The reason people make alliances is this one as well: if you make an alliance with someone, then you have access to their economic and military power.

Even people that obtain power through more “feminine” means are also obtaining military power. Let’s take Sansa as an example. She’s currently in the Vale, trying to marry Harry to assume power in the Vale and take back Winterfell. You could say that her ways of obtaining power are more “traditionally feminine”. But ultimately, what it actually means is that if she marries Harry and Robert Arryn dies, she’ll have access to the power and armies of the Vale. And she’ll use this military power to forcefully take Winterfell back. Even if she makes alliances with the Northern houses, these alliances are important because of the military power that comes with them.

Besides, if Dany wants to defeat the slavers or become queen of Westeros, she needs to do it by force. I’m repeating myself here, but I don’t care: Westeros is not a democracy. Dany can’t sign up for the next Westerosi presidential elections, there’s no way for her to take power that doesn’t involve force. Dany herself tell us this:

“Yet I must have some army,” Dany said. “The boy Joffrey will not give me the Iron Throne for asking politely.” – Daenerys II ASOS

She’s right. No one will give her the Iron Throne by asking politely, just like the Boltons won’t give Winterfell back to the Starks by asking politely. They are not going to hold elections to decide if the rulers of the North should be the Boltons or the Starks. The Starks, just like Dany, will have to use force.

With all of this being said, I do think that Dany has some internalized sexism, like the time in which she says that she believes that it’s her son that will rule Westeros, and not her. But every character in this story is sexist in some way, because this is a patriarchal society. And I don’t think that the arguments of the antis hold much water. Dany does ask about Elia and Elia, and the use of military power is a necessity for any ruler. Having military power doesn’t make Dany “toxically masculine”. Antis keep saying things like “if only Dany was kind and gentle and embraced ‘feminine qualities’ she would be such a better ruler”. But this is wrong. First, because Dany is kind and gentle. Second, because being kind and gentle doesn’t mean you will be a good ruler. Power will not fall into your lap if you just “embrace your femininity”. Being a ruling queen means that Dany has to deal with the kind of power that is usually seen as masculine, like commanding armies, dealing with justice, and using force. Ruling is something seen as masculine. What I actually think is sexist is this idea that a woman must always conform to gender roles and be “feminine”. What’s sexist is this idea that if a woman assumes a masculine-coded position like being a ruling queen, then she’s “toxically masculine” and evil. This whole discourse around Dany just goes to prove how much people are uncomfortable with women in positions of power.

reblog.comment:
There’s a lot of things to discuss in your ask. First, the question of Elia and Rhaella. @nobodysuspectsthebutterfly made two posts about this, and you can read them here and here.

Saying that Dany has no interest of learning about Elia and Rhaella is very unfair. Most of what we know about Elia and Rhaella come from Oberyn, from Jaime, from the World of Ice and Fire book, and because Dany asks questions about them. Dany is interested in learning about them. This is Dany asking about her mother:

Ser Barristan went on. “I saw your father and your mother wed as well. Forgive me, but there was no fondness there, and the realm paid dearly for that, my queen.”

“Why did they wed if they did not love each other?”

“Your grandsire commanded it. A woods witch had told him that the prince was promised would be born of their line.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

“Tell me,” Dany said, as the procession turned toward the Temple of the Graces, “if my father and my mother had been free to follow their own hearts, whom would they have wed?”

“It was long ago. Your Grace would not know them.”

“You know, though. Tell me.”

The old knight inclined his head. “The queen your mother was always mindful of her duty.” He was handsome in his gold-and-silver armor, his white cloak streaming from his shoulders, but he sounded like a man in pain, as if every word were a stone he had to pass. “As a girl, though … she was once smitten with a young knight from the stormlands who wore her favor at a tourney and named her queen of love and beauty. A brief thing.”

“What happened to this knight?”

“He put away his lance the day your lady mother wed your father. Afterward he became most pious, and was heard to say that only the Maiden could replace Queen Rhaella in his heart. His passion was impossible, of course. A landed knight is no fit consort for a princess of royal blood.” – Daenerys VII ADWD

Dany also thinks a lot about Elia and her children, and asks questions about them:

Yet sometimes Dany would picture the way it had been, so often had her brother told her the stories. The midnight flight to Dragonstone, moonlight shimmering on the ship’s black sails. Her brother Rhaegar battling the Usurper in the bloody waters of the Trident and dying for the woman he loved. The sack of King’s Landing by the ones Viserys called the Usurper’s dogs, the lords Lannister and Stark. Princess Elia of Dorne pleading for mercy as Rhaegar’s heir was ripped from her breast and murdered before her eyes. The polished skulls of the last dragons staring down sightlessly from the walls of the throne room while the Kingslayer opened Father’s throat with a golden sword. – Daenerys I AGOT

She nodded. “There was a woman in a bed with a babe at her breast. My brother said the babe was the prince that was promised and told her to name him Aegon.”

“Prince Aegon was Rhaegar’s heir by Elia of Dorne,” Ser Jorah said. “But if he was this prince that was promised, the promise was broken along with his skull when the Lannisters dashed his head against a wall.”

“I remember,” Dany said sadly. “They murdered Rhaegar’s daughter as well, the little princess. Rhaenys, she was named, like Aegon’s sister. There was no Visenya, but he said the dragon has three heads. What is the song of ice and fire?” – Daenerys V ACOK

“But that was the tourney when he crowned Lyanna Stark as queen of love and beauty!” said Dany. “Princess Elia was there, his wife, and yet my brother gave the crown to the Stark girl, and later stole her away from her betrothed. How could he do that? Did the Dornish woman treat him so ill?”

“It is not for such as me to say what might have been in your brother’s heart, Your Grace. The Princess Elia was a good and gracious lady, though her health was ever delicate.” – Daenerys IV ASOS

“You saw my brother Rhaegar wed. Tell me, did he wed for love or duty?”

The old knight hesitated. “Princess Elia was a good woman, Your Grace. She was kind and clever, with a gentle heart and a sweet wit. I know the prince was very fond of her.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

As you can see, Dany is interested, and she constantly thinks about the injustice made against Elia and her children. Besides, if we know little about these women, this isn’t Dany’s fault. It’s GRRM’s fault for not being interested in writing about them. This is a problem in GRRM’s writing. I’m tired of seeing Dany being blamed for the problems in the narrative. These problems aren’t her fault. I’ve also seen people in the fandom criticize Dany for this line:

“But that was the tourney when he crowned Lyanna Stark as queen of love and beauty!” said Dany. “Princess Elia was there, his wife, and yet my brother gave the crown to the Stark girl, and later stole her away from her betrothed. How could he do that? Did the Dornish woman treat him so ill?”

Antis say that Dany is “victim blaming” Elia. But I also think this criticism is very unfair. Because everything that Dany knows about Rhaegar from other people has been positive. She has been told all of these stories about how Rhaegar was honorable, just and good. With all of that, she can’t imagine why would Rhaegar publicly humiliate his wife. She even asks “how could he do that?” She’s appalled by the idea that Rhaegar would do something like that, so she asks for an explanation. Then, she tells Ser Barristan about what Viserys would tell her, how he used to be an emotionally abusive asshole that blamed both her and Elia for Rhaegar not being happy:

“It is not for such as me to say what might have been in your brother’s heart, Your Grace. The Princess Elia was a good and gracious lady, though her health was ever delicate.” 

Dany pulled the lion pelt tighter about her shoulders. “Viserys said once that it was my fault, for being born too late.” She had denied it hotly, she remembered, going so far as to tell Viserys that it was his fault for not being born a girl. He beat her cruelly for that insolence. “If I had been born more timely, he said, Rhaegar would have married me instead of Elia, and it would all have come out different. If Rhaegar had been happy in his wife, he would not have needed the Stark girl.” – Daenerys IV ASOS

I’m sorry, but Dany doesn’t know the full story, and even worse, she had Viserys telling her all these incorrect things. Viserys even emotionally and physically abused her for questioning his version of the facts. I’m tired of seeing this fandom blame Dany for things that she doesn’t know, as if she’s somehow obligated to be omniscient and know all the bad stuff about Rhaegar and her father. Dany doesn’t know that. For all she knew, Rhaegar was a very good person, so it’s natural that she would ask for an explanation about what happened. But notice that when Ser Barristan tells her the truth, Dany never tries to contradict him. She never tells him “no, you’re lying, Elia must have done something bad, she must be blamed”. Dany DOES NOT blame Elia. She was simply asking a question, because she doesn’t know anything about what happened.

Finally, let’s talk about this idea that Dany believes in “a power that destroys and oppresses”. I think there are different levels of wrong with this.

First: antis seem to have this idea that the only way Dany knows how to keep power is through war and force (hard power). This is wrong. Dany’s entire storyline in ADWD is about making compromises to keep peace, using soft power, and rebuilding (the only thing Dany is “destroying” is the slave trade). Dany dislikes violence. She’s actually a very flexible ruler that tries everything she can to accommodate the needs of different people: she adapts to other cultures, she makes several concessions in Meereen, she tries everything she can to find peaceful solutions. The idea that Dany only maintains power through violence and destruction and that she “doesn’t question it” is ridiculously wrong:

What good is peace if it must be purchased with the blood of little children? “These murders are not their doing,” Dany told the Green Grace, feebly. “I am no butcher queen.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

“Zhak and Pahl and Merreq. Them, and all the rest. The Great Masters. Who else would it be?”

He is as bold as he is bloody. “We have no proof this is their work. Would you have me slaughter my own subjects?”

[…]

“Then winkle them out of their pyramids on some pretext. A wedding might serve. Why not? Promise your hand to Hizdahr and all the Great Masters will come to see you married. When they gather in the Temple of the Graces, turn us loose upon them.”

Dany was appalled. He is a monster. A gallant monster, but a monster still. “Do you take me for the Butcher King?”

“Better the butcher than the meat. All kings are butchers. Are queens so different?”

“This queen is.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

Only at the end of ADWD does Dany reject the peace, and the reason for that is that the peace was unjust. Dany had to accept things like seeing people dying in the fighting pits and allowing slavery to return outside Meereen. A peace with slavery means that people will suffer continuous violence (slaves are beaten, raped, mutilated, overworked, treated like things). A peace with slavery is no true peace. I think Dany is right in being unsatisfied with a peace like that.

Second: this idea that any ruler could eschew military power is ridiculous. @instantbouquetface-me wrote a great post about this. You can read it here. But basically, as Max Weber says, any state “claims the monopoly of the legitimate use of physical force within a given territory”. Military power is part of that. Unless antis want Dany to help Westeros or Meereen to become an anarchy (I highly doubt that), then she needs military power as well. That’s how everyone (Starks, Targaryens, Lannisters, everyone) gains and keeps power. The Starks didn’t become Kings in the North by asking politely and making friends. They became Kings in the North through conquest.

Even rulers that are considered to be conciliators, like Jaehaerys and Alysanne, kept their power through threat of violence. Actually, no one would need to make compromises if military power wasn’t important. The reason Dany has to make compromises in Meereen is because she doesn’t have enough military power to defeat her enemies (and her dragons are chained), and because her enemies have military and economic power that they can use against her. The reason people make alliances is this one as well: if you make an alliance with someone, then you have access to their economic and military power.

Even people that obtain power through more “feminine” means are also obtaining military power. Let’s take Sansa as an example. She’s currently in the Vale, trying to marry Harry to assume power in the Vale and take back Winterfell. You could say that her ways of obtaining power are more “traditionally feminine”. But ultimately, what it actually means is that if she marries Harry and Robert Arryn dies, she’ll have access to the power and armies of the Vale. And she’ll use this military power to forcefully take Winterfell back. Even if she makes alliances with the Northern houses, these alliances are important because of the military power that comes with them.

Besides, if Dany wants to defeat the slavers or become queen of Westeros, she needs to do it by force. I’m repeating myself here, but I don’t care: Westeros is not a democracy. Dany can’t sign up for the next Westerosi presidential elections, there’s no way for her to take power that doesn’t involve force. Dany herself tell us this:

“Yet I must have some army,” Dany said. “The boy Joffrey will not give me the Iron Throne for asking politely.” – Daenerys II ASOS

She’s right. No one will give her the Iron Throne by asking politely, just like the Boltons won’t give Winterfell back to the Starks by asking politely. They are not going to hold elections to decide if the rulers of the North should be the Boltons or the Starks. The Starks, just like Dany, will have to use force.

With all of this being said, I do think that Dany has some internalized sexism, like the time in which she says that she believes that it’s her son that will rule Westeros, and not her. But every character in this story is sexist in some way, because this is a patriarchal society. And I don’t think that the arguments of the antis hold much water. Dany does ask about Elia and Elia, and the use of military power is a necessity for any ruler. Having military power doesn’t make Dany “toxically masculine”. Antis keep saying things like “if only Dany was kind and gentle and embraced ‘feminine qualities’ she would be such a better ruler”. But this is wrong. First, because Dany is kind and gentle. Second, because being kind and gentle doesn’t mean you will be a good ruler. Power will not fall into your lap if you just “embrace your femininity”. Being a ruling queen means that Dany has to deal with the kind of power that is usually seen as masculine, like commanding armies, dealing with justice, and using force. Ruling is something seen as masculine. What I actually think is sexist is this idea that a woman must always conform to gender roles and be “feminine”. What’s sexist is this idea that if a woman assumes a masculine-coded position like being a ruling queen, then she’s “toxically masculine” and evil. This whole discourse around Dany just goes to prove how much people are uncomfortable with women in positions of power.

Dany pulled the lion pelt tighter about her shoulders. “Viserys said once that it was my fault, for being born too late.” She had denied it hotly, she remembered, going so far as to tell Viserys that it was his fault for not being born a girl. “Your grandsire commanded it. A woods witch had told him that the prince was promised would be born of their line.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

“It was long ago. Your Grace would not know them.”

The old knight inclined his head. “The queen your mother was always mindful of her duty.” He was handsome in his gold-and-silver armor, his white cloak streaming from his shoulders, but he sounded like a man in pain, as if every word were a stone he had to pass. “As a girl, though … she was once smitten with a young knight from the stormlands who wore her favor at a tourney and named her queen of love and beauty. A brief thing.”

“What happened to this knight?”

“He put away his lance the day your lady mother wed your father. Afterward he became most pious, and was heard to say that only the Maiden could replace Queen Rhaella in his heart. His passion was impossible, of course. A landed knight is no fit consort for a princess of royal blood.” – Daenerys VII ADWD

The polished skulls of the last dragons staring down sightlessly from the walls of the throne room while the Kingslayer opened Father’s throat with a golden sword. – Daenerys I AGOT

She nodded. “There was a woman in a bed with a babe at her breast. My brother said the babe was the prince that was promised and told her to name him Aegon.”

“Prince Aegon was Rhaegar’s heir by Elia of Dorne,” Ser Jorah said. “But if he was this prince that was promised, the promise was broken along with his skull when the Lannisters dashed his head against a wall.”

“I remember,” Dany said sadly. “They murdered Rhaegar’s daughter as well, the little princess. Rhaenys, she was named, like Aegon’s sister. There was no Visenya, but he said the dragon has three heads. What is the song of ice and fire?” – Daenerys V ACOK

“It is not for such as me to say what might have been in your brother’s heart, Your Grace. The Princess Elia was a good and gracious lady, though her health was ever delicate.” – Daenerys IV ASOS

“You saw my brother Rhaegar wed. Tell me, did he wed for love or duty?”

The old knight hesitated. “Princess Elia was a good woman, Your Grace. She was kind and clever, with a gentle heart and a sweet wit. I know the prince was very fond of her.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

It’s GRRM’s fault for not being interested in writing about them. This is a problem in GRRM’s writing. I’m tired of seeing Dany being blamed for the problems in the narrative. These problems aren’t her fault. I’ve also seen people in the fandom criticize Dany for this line:

“But that was the tourney when he crowned Lyanna Stark as queen of love and beauty!” said Dany. “Princess Elia was there, his wife, and yet my brother gave the crown to the Stark girl, and later stole her away from her betrothed. How could he do that? Did the Dornish woman treat him so ill?”

Antis say that Dany is “victim blaming” Elia. But I also think this criticism is very unfair. Because everything that Dany knows about Rhaegar from other people has been positive. She has been told all of these stories about how Rhaegar was honorable, just and good. With all of that, she can’t imagine why would Rhaegar publicly humiliate his wife. She even asks “how could he do that?” She’s appalled by the idea that Rhaegar would do something like that, so she asks for an explanation. Then, she tells Ser Barristan about what Viserys would tell her, how he used to be an emotionally abusive asshole that blamed both her and Elia for Rhaegar not being happy:

“It is not for such as me to say what might have been in your brother’s heart, Your Grace. The Princess Elia was a good and gracious lady, though her health was ever delicate.” 

Dany pulled the lion pelt tighter about her shoulders. “Viserys said once that it was my fault, for being born too late.” She had denied it hotly, she remembered, going so far as to tell Viserys that it was his fault for not being born a girl. He beat her cruelly for that insolence. “If I had been born more timely, he said, Rhaegar would have married me instead of Elia, and it would all have come out different. If Rhaegar had been happy in his wife, he would not have needed the Stark girl.” – Daenerys IV ASOS

I’m sorry, but Dany doesn’t know the full story, and even worse, she had Viserys telling her all these incorrect things. Viserys even emotionally and physically abused her for questioning his version of the facts. I’m tired of seeing this fandom blame Dany for things that she doesn’t know, as if she’s somehow obligated to be omniscient and know all the bad stuff about Rhaegar and her father. Dany doesn’t know that. For all she knew, Rhaegar was a very good person, so it’s natural that she would ask for an explanation about what happened. But notice that when Ser Barristan tells her the truth, Dany never tries to contradict him. She never tells him “no, you’re lying, Elia must have done something bad, she must be blamed”. Dany DOES NOT blame Elia. She was simply asking a question, because she doesn’t know anything about what happened.

Finally, let’s talk about this idea that Dany believes in “a power that destroys and oppresses”. I think there are different levels of wrong with this.

First: antis seem to have this idea that the only way Dany knows how to keep power is through war and force (hard power). This is wrong. Dany’s entire storyline in ADWD is about making compromises to keep peace, using soft power, and rebuilding (the only thing Dany is “destroying” is the slave trade). Dany dislikes violence. She’s actually a very flexible ruler that tries everything she can to accommodate the needs of different people: she adapts to other cultures, she makes several concessions in Meereen, she tries everything she can to find peaceful solutions. The idea that Dany only maintains power through violence and destruction and that she “doesn’t question it” is ridiculously wrong:

What good is peace if it must be purchased with the blood of little children? “These murders are not their doing,” Dany told the Green Grace, feebly. “I am no butcher queen.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

“Zhak and Pahl and Merreq. Them, and all the rest. The Great Masters. Who else would it be?”

He is as bold as he is bloody. “We have no proof this is their work. Would you have me slaughter my own subjects?”

[…]

“Then winkle them out of their pyramids on some pretext. A wedding might serve. Why not? Promise your hand to Hizdahr and all the Great Masters will come to see you married. When they gather in the Temple of the Graces, turn us loose upon them.”

Dany was appalled. He is a monster. A gallant monster, but a monster still. “Do you take me for the Butcher King?”

“Better the butcher than the meat. All kings are butchers. Are queens so different?”

“This queen is.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

Only at the end of ADWD does Dany reject the peace, and the reason for that is that the peace was unjust. Dany had to accept things like seeing people dying in the fighting pits and allowing slavery to return outside Meereen. A peace with slavery means that people will suffer continuous violence (slaves are beaten, raped, mutilated, overworked, treated like things). A peace with slavery is no true peace. I think Dany is right in being unsatisfied with a peace like that.

Second: this idea that any ruler could eschew military power is ridiculous. @instantbouquetface-me wrote a great post about this. You can read it here. But basically, as Max Weber says, any state “claims the monopoly of the legitimate use of physical force within a given territory”. Military power is part of that. Unless antis want Dany to help Westeros or Meereen to become an anarchy (I highly doubt that), then she needs military power as well. That’s how everyone (Starks, Targaryens, Lannisters, everyone) gains and keeps power. The Starks didn’t become Kings in the North by asking politely and making friends. They became Kings in the North through conquest.

Even rulers that are considered to be conciliators, like Jaehaerys and Alysanne, kept their power through threat of violence. Actually, no one would need to make compromises if military power wasn’t important. The reason Dany has to make compromises in Meereen is because she doesn’t have enough military power to defeat her enemies (and her dragons are chained), and because her enemies have military and economic power that they can use against her. The reason people make alliances is this one as well: if you make an alliance with someone, then you have access to their economic and military power.

Even people that obtain power through more “feminine” means are also obtaining military power. Let’s take Sansa as an example. She’s currently in the Vale, trying to marry Harry to assume power in the Vale and take back Winterfell. You could say that her ways of obtaining power are more “traditionally feminine”. But ultimately, what it actually means is that if she marries Harry and Robert Arryn dies, she’ll have access to the power and armies of the Vale. And she’ll use this military power to forcefully take Winterfell back. Even if she makes alliances with the Northern houses, these alliances are important because of the military power that comes with them.

Besides, if Dany wants to defeat the slavers or become queen of Westeros, she needs to do it by force. I’m repeating myself here, but I don’t care: Westeros is not a democracy. Dany can’t sign up for the next Westerosi presidential elections, there’s no way for her to take power that doesn’t involve force. Dany herself tell us this:

“Yet I must have some army,” Dany said. “The boy Joffrey will not give me the Iron Throne for asking politely.” – Daenerys II ASOS

She’s right. No one will give her the Iron Throne by asking politely, just like the Boltons won’t give Winterfell back to the Starks by asking politely. They are not going to hold elections to decide if the rulers of the North should be the Boltons or the Starks. The Starks, just like Dany, will have to use force.

With all of this being said, I do think that Dany has some internalized sexism, like the time in which she says that she believes that it’s her son that will rule Westeros, and not her. But every character in this story is sexist in some way, because this is a patriarchal society. And I don’t think that the arguments of the antis hold much water. Dany does ask about Elia and Elia, and the use of military power is a necessity for any ruler. Having military power doesn’t make Dany “toxically masculine”. Antis keep saying things like “if only Dany was kind and gentle and embraced ‘feminine qualities’ she would be such a better ruler”. But this is wrong. First, because Dany is kind and gentle. Second, because being kind and gentle doesn’t mean you will be a good ruler. Power will not fall into your lap if you just “embrace your femininity”. Being a ruling queen means that Dany has to deal with the kind of power that is usually seen as masculine, like commanding armies, dealing with justice, and using force. Ruling is something seen as masculine. What I actually think is sexist is this idea that a woman must always conform to gender roles and be “feminine”. What’s sexist is this idea that if a woman assumes a masculine-coded position like being a ruling queen, then she’s “toxically masculine” and evil. This whole discourse around Dany just goes to prove how much people are uncomfortable with women in positions of power.

summary: In regards to the northern armor for Jamie. The daughter of the queen he loved but couldn’t save, and the son of the prince he...
question: In regards to the northern armor for Jamie. The daughter of the queen he loved but couldn’t save, and the son of the prince he loved and couldn’t save, the last of the children he was charged with protecting, are now wearing northern clothes (or always were). His wardrobe makes sense to me.
answer:
Hey friend,

That’s true and something I didn’t really think about. Especially with Jon, Jaime felt very guilty about not being able to protect his children so he might feel that he could make amend by protecting Jon. Although, they haven’t really discussed this on the show, so who knows what angle they are going to go with. But those are some very nice point. 

TTFN
